instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1990: What is A1990? A1990 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2018, 2019 with EMC3215, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01041, 820-01814..
definitions.820-01041: What is 820-01041? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PM_EN_P3V3_G3H: What is PM_EN_P3V3_G3H? PM_EN_P3V3_G3H is a signal that enables the PP3V3_G3H rail to turn on. This comes out of ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip; when missing, often is missing because of a bad ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.C7050: What is C7050? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for battery current sensing, you should measure around 2.202 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won‚Äôt charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.3V3_G3H_RTC: What is 3V3_G3H_RTC? 3V3_G3H_RTC Is an abbreviation of PP3V3_G3H_RTC which is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.SMC_LID_LEFT: What is SMC_LID_LEFT? SMC_LID_LEFT is a signal that tells the system if the lid is closed from the left LID sensor. If it is low, the system thinks the lid is closed ‚Äì if it is 3.3v, the system thinks the machine is open. SMC_LID_LEFT needs to be high for the machine to stay awake and have a backlight. .
definitions.CD3214: What is CD3214? This is a common typo,  the person typing CD3214 was most likely referring to CD3215.
definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: [HELP]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> NOBOOT, STRANGE!
threads.message:
Hi to all...<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no liquid spill...3 usb ports stuck on 5v, the other port totally dead

Because of a small journey, I‚Äôve ask a friend of mine, technician, to change the controller corresponding to the dead port

I don‚Äôt know why, I have changed all 4 controller

now i have 5v@0,269 on all 4 ports

According to this guide

[URL unfurl="true"]https://logi.wiki/index.php/CD3215_Bootup_Sequence[/URL]

I confirm that

i have all ldo's...

i have <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>
i have <SIGNAL>TBA_VDDA</SIGNAL> (<SIGNAL>PPCHGR_VDDA</SIGNAL>)
i have <SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> (<SIGNAL>NC_CHGR_EN_VR1</SIGNAL>)
i have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>

i can't find in schematic <SIGNAL>PP1V2_G3H_SMC_VDDC</SIGNAL> or <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S5_SMC_VDDC</SIGNAL>
i can't find in schematic <SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H_AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> or <SIGNAL>PP3V0_S5_AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL>
if it is <SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>, i have 3,3v

i can't find <SIGNAL>SMC_RST</SIGNAL>, if it is <SIGNAL>TP_CHGR_SMC_RST_L</SIGNAL>, i have 1,7 and not 3v

if i connect the upper left or right port to my mac m1, i receive the message

"impossible to use accessory"

if i try to connect the others two ports, nothing happen

please help and sorry for my bad english!

threads.title: [HELP]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> NOBOOT, STRANGE!
threads.message:
Do you get 1V1 LDO BMC on the corresponding powered port?
Test connecting charger to all ports.

Are you using original 87W charger?
Machine turns on with battery connected?

What is the exact <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage?
If missing, remove F7000/1 and check <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> voltage.

threads.title: [HELP]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> NOBOOT, STRANGE!
threads.message:
CC1/2 pins change the voltage, according which direction is connected the charger on the corresponding port.

Check diode mode on all big coils and compare with good board, or refference table.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://openboarddata.org/?a=showboardsolutions&bpath=laptops/apple/<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>[/URL]
Don't forget L9080/580.

Try to put the machine in DFU using wire method.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://logi.wiki/index.php/DFU_Mode_Restore_(Macs)#/media/File:<SIGNAL>SOC_FORCE_DFU_JUMPER</SIGNAL>.jpg[/URL]

threads.message:
Do you know what these values for coils mean???
Don't get confused man.
Internal specifications of the coils, have nothing to see with diode mode (or ohm resistance) to ground.

If T2 gets all SLPS2R and AWAKE required voltage, it should go into DFU.
Be sure to use all steps to enter DFU correctly.

threads.title: [HELP]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> NOBOOT, STRANGE!
threads.message:
"asked me to check all coils in diode mode"
We use the coils as test points for the secondary power supplies output!

What do you expect to get in diode mode (or ohm scale), measuring between a coil pins?
The coil is a short in DC mode!

Personally I prefer to solder a small switch (with 5-10cm wires) over the force DFU pads.
Machine should enter to DFU after 5-10s, starting with the switch closed.
If not, force it off (power button) and try again.
Sometime I got in DFU maintaining the switch closed when i forced the machine off.
I fight with an A1949 two days until I got in DFU.
This is not as easy as you think.
Apple did a "good job", for its interest.

Some peoples claimed they couldn't get in DFU with original Apple cables.
Even the macOS installed in the host machine may impede to detect the target machine correctly with AC2.

"0v on <RESISTOR>R6941</RESISTOR> (<SIGNAL>UPC_PMU_RESET</SIGNAL>)"
Good enough, we don't want the machine in reset state.

threads.title: [HELP]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> NOBOOT, STRANGE!
threads.message:
You should get similar readings on 01814, even 00850 boards; in the USB-C areas.

Be aware to solder correct <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips, with the same code termination; C00, A12, B03 not interchangeable.
You can solder and test one by one.

threads.title: [HELP]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> NOBOOT, STRANGE!
threads.message:
Did you solder the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips with correct termination?
C00, A12, B03 are not interchangeable.

If <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> delivers all required SLPS2R and AWAKE voltages, board should enter DFU.
If not, there is a problem with T2 chip or communication through corresponding DFU port.
If you replaced all <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips and checked all ports, probably T2 is the culprit.

threads.message:
I don't see <RESISTOR>R4807</RESISTOR>/8 marked as "NO STUFF", so we expect to be present.
However, may not be needed if pull-up resistors are included inside lid sensors J4800/1.
Just check <SIGNAL>SMC_LID_LEFT</SIGNAL>/RIGHT signals; should be high when open the lid.

So actually only one port switches to 20V?
Before changing <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips, all ports switched to 20V?

threads.title: [HELP]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> NOBOOT, STRANGE!
threads.message:
OL means open line, no connection.
May be caused by incorrect solders under <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips, or broken traces.
I recommend to check directly on J3300 and JB500 in diode mode.

S-UEM2 tool is better for this purpose.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://www.google.com/search?client=firefox-b-d&sca_esv=579431573&hl=es&sxsrf=AM9HkKlGYzdloF_GM-8-va03FYRA2oRoQQ:1699276747809&q=s-uem2&tbm=isch&source=lnms&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjgkbaXu6-CAxX6UKQEHa1yDCUQ0pQJegQIDRAB&biw=1536&bih=630&dpr=1.25[/URL]

You can also test replacing USB-C cables.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://es.aliexpress.com/item/1005004265288371.html?src=google&src=google&albch=shopping&acnt=439-079-4345&slnk=&plac=&mtctp=&albbt=Google_7_shopping&albagn=888888&isSmbAutoCall=false&needSmbHouyi=false&albcp=20330803848&albag=&trgt=&crea=es1005004265288371&netw=x&device=c&albpg=&albpd=es1005004265288371&gclid=Cj0KCQiAuqKqBhDxARIsAFZELmI26FYprMOpE-J_m-sVlYsVlHrSKsGhLA317Wk0sblqp3IoGyGeqr0aAisLEALw_wcB&gclsrc=aw.ds&aff_fcid=f9e2e3d40ef2432da7a5ecfee56c6860-1699276835447-05094-UneMJZVf&aff_fsk=UneMJZVf&aff_platform=aaf&sk=UneMJZVf&aff_trace_key=f9e2e3d40ef2432da7a5ecfee56c6860-1699276835447-05094-UneMJZVf&terminal_id=aa99aa154f2b4fe2bee8a5be8dfc1523&afSmartRedirect=y[/URL]

threads.title: [HELP]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> NOBOOT, STRANGE!
threads.message:
S-UEM2 will give high readings (24xx) for not connected pins (NC) as normal.
But will indicate the wrong values with up/down arrows; like 24xx instead of 293.

When you have doubts, is better to manually check corresponding pins in diode mode directly on the board.

OL means no connection; broken trace, or bad solders.

"i have 2,5v instead of 1v8 on <CAPACITOR>C3206</CAPACITOR>, how is it possible"

Not expected voltages on QB300/400 because these ports don't switch to 20V yet.

threads.title: [HELP]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> NOBOOT, STRANGE!
threads.message:
All <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips must be present on board.
T2 (SMC part) must "talk" with each one to find the powered port, then will start the communication with the charger.

On each side you have a primary and secondary chip.
Not sure how Apple used this terminology, as <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> boots first (on left side) from <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>.
<CHIP>U3100</CHIP> boots from <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> through UART lines.
You may have problems with <TRANSISTOR>Q3200</TRANSISTOR>, or its traces.

Similar theory applies to UB400/300.
Not switching at all to 20V on right side, may be caused by UB090 problems.

threads.title: [HELP]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> NOBOOT, STRANGE!
threads.message:
J3300 is the left connector; look at the board as in normal working position, mounted in the housing.
However, this is not important here.

As I said, check all resistors around <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>/200 and their traces/solders.
Just in case, replace <TRANSISTOR>Q3200</TRANSISTOR>.

On the right side (UB300/400), try reflashing UB090.

threads.title: [HELP]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> NOBOOT, STRANGE!
threads.message:
You should tahe the readings when the charger is connected to corresponding port.
Can also use an o-scope to compare TBT SPI signals, according with the powered ports.

<CHIP>U2800</CHIP> and UB000 are also connected to TBT SPI chips and can affect them.
May suspect UB000, as none of its ports switch to 20V.
You should also remove and check (out of board) each dual MOSFET paired with <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips; except the working one.
